Yes, The Criterion Collection is also known for bringing many classic foreign films to the attention of American audiences. Here are a few examples of foreign films that The Criterion Collection has popularized:

1. Paris, Texas (1984) - A German film directed by Wim Wenders that tells the story of a man who wanders out of the desert and tries to reconnect with his family in Texas. It's a haunting and beautiful film that has become a cult classic.

2. La Grande Illusion (1937) - A French film directed by Jean Renoir that explores the relationships between French and German prisoners of war during World War I. It's a stunning anti-war film that was revolutionary in its use of sound and camera techniques.

3. Yojimbo (1961) - A Japanese film directed by Akira Kurosawa that tells the story of a samurai who plays two rival factions against each other. It's a thrilling and visually stunning film that has influenced countless other movies.

4. Come and See (1985) - A Soviet Union film directed by Elem Klimov that depicts the horror of the Nazi invasion of Belarus during World War II. It's an uncompromising and devastating film that is widely considered one of the greatest war movies ever made.

5. Jules and Jim (1962) - A French film directed by François Truffaut that tells the story of two men who fall in love with the same woman. It's a tender and poetic film that explores the complexities of love and friendship.

6. Red Desert (1964) - An Italian film directed by Michelangelo Antonioni that depicts the emotional struggles of a woman living in a bleak industrial landscape. It's a visually stunning film that explores themes of alienation and despair.

These are just a few examples of the many foreign films that The Criterion Collection has helped to popularize in the US. By bringing these films to a wider audience and providing context and special features that enhance our understanding of them, The Criterion Collection has enriched our appreciation of cinema as a truly global art form.
